I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  During  the  2003  Country  Programming  Mission,  the  Government  of  the  People's 
Republic of China (PRC) requested the Asian Development Bank (ADB) for technical assistance 
(TA) to the Ministry of Finance (MOF) to reform agricultural taxation. In response, the Fact-
Finding Mission1 visited Beijing on 17–21 May 2004, and reached an understanding with MOF 
on  the  TA  objectives,  scope,  and  implementation  arrangements.2  The  TA  framework  is  in 
Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  The  PRC’s  agricultural  taxes  are  based  on  1958  regulations  and  constitute  a  dual 
system for urban and rural residents. Agricultural taxes are levied according to product price, 
plot area, and average yield per plot area in 5 years. Cash crops are covered by the agricultural 
special product tax and animal husbandry tax. Local governments,3 especially of counties and 
villages, charged fees legally and illegally from farmers for various purposes, often more than 
the formal tax, especially in poor areas.4 Other tax instruments such as the value-added tax 
(VAT) and income and land-usage taxes, however, are not applied to farmers. Different levels of 
governments rely on different tax instruments as their major revenue sources: VAT for the 
central Government, corporate taxes for high-level local governments, and agricultural taxes for 
low-level local governments.5 Many low-level governments have fiscal deficits. The central and 
provincial governments have revenue transfer systems to help local governments provide basic 
services and to level the revenue imbalances between local governments. 
 
3.  One of the largest problems of the PRC’s tax system is the disproportionately heavy 
burden on farmers, who are generally poorer than urban residents. The average income of 
farmers was CNY2,622 in 2003, less than a third of the urban residents’ average, CNY8,472. 
The income gap between urban and rural residents is widening. During the past 6 years (1997–
2003), farmers’ average income grew by 3.9% per year, and urban residents’ by 8.6%. Despite 
such an uneven income distribution and a growing gap, many rural residents have been levied 
heavy  taxes  and  fees  due  to,  among  other  reasons,  (i)  disproportionate  and  regressive 
agricultural  tax  systems,  (ii)  lack  of  local  governments’  alternative  revenues  sources,  and         
(iii) high cost of rural public services due to overstaffing and inefficient governance. 
 
 4.  The burden sharing among farmers is not adequate. Because the agricultural tax is 
based on plot area and average yield and no progressive tax system is applied to farmers, 
some wealthy farmers enjoy relatively low taxes while low-income farmers have to pay relatively 
high taxes. Tax imposition is not adequately correlated with capacity to pay. The tax system 
discourages farmers from investing in and enlarging farmland because the tax is based on plot 
area, with no consideration for actual production costs. The agricultural tax system is outdated, 
inadequate for a market economy, unfair to farmers, and a hindrance to agricultural and rural

economic development. The Government recognizes the need for an equitable agricultural tax 
system and balanced rural public finance. 
 
5.  To lighten the heavy burden on farmers, the Government launched rural tax and fee 
reforms in Anhui Province as a pilot project in 2000, and spread them all over the country in 
2003. The reform program aims, among other things, to (i) abolish most of the fees and restrain 
local governments from discretionally charging fees, (ii) replace a part of originally legal fees 
with an increased agricultural tax rate, and (iii) establish a democratic procedure for deciding fee 
charges in villages.6 As a result, disorderly fee charges by local governments were restrained in 
most areas, and the overall tax and fee burden declined by 30–40%. However, these measures 
also reduced the revenues of local governments and aggravated their financial burden. The 
Government thus allowed for more revenue transfer from the upper- to lower-level governments.  
 
6.  In March 2004, the Government announced that it would abolish the agricultural special 
product tax (except for tobacco) this year and gradually reduce the agricultural tax to zero by 
2008. As the first step, MOF, Ministry of Agriculture, and state tax administration (STA) jointly 
issued a note in April 2004 to (i) reduce the agricultural tax by 1% all over the country and          
(ii) nominate several pilot provinces where taxes would be reduced or exempted.7 If the two 
taxes are abolished, the farmers will benefit. However, the revenue of low-level governments, 
which rely heavily on agricultural taxes, will be severely reduced. Low-level governments mainly 
provide basic public services such as education, public health, and social security. 
 
7.  The Government plans to compensate the local governments by transferring revenues to 
low-level governments. However, an equitable tax system must also be gradually established 
while balancing local governments’ public finance needs since (i) a limited number of wealthy 
farmers should be levied taxes, (ii) overreliance on revenue transfer will encourage low-level 
governments to strive for maximum revenue transfer and discourage expenditure control, and 
(iii) continued revenue transfer may heavily burden the central Government. 
 
8.  Coverage of other tax items8 must be expanded to make taxation equitable. Countries 
with unified tax systems can make taxation equitable through income and property taxes and 
VAT. To levy these taxes on farmers, tax authorities need to learn, among other things, how to 
(i) calculate the income and value addition from agricultural production, (ii) assess the value of 
farmlands  and  forests,  and  (iii)  deal  with  farmers  who  are  unable  to  prepare  necessary 
documents (e.g., accounting books). To prevent the upturn of the tax burden on poor farmers 
and to encourage investment in agriculture, tax rebates and exemption schemes and other 
fiscal treatments should also be considered. Since the PRC has never had unified urban and 
rural  tax  systems,  the  Government  must  learn  about  international  practices  to  design  tax 
policies, collection methods, and implementation arrangements and strategies for a unified tax 
system. The tax administration system’s capacities should also be strengthened. 
 
9.  Public finance responsibilities of different levels of government must also be defined. To 
decide such allocations, not only the balance between revenues and expenses but also the 
nature of each tax item, cost for tax collection, and capacities of different tax administration 
authorities should be considered. Since local government revenue in rural areas may decline as

improving basic rural public services. To strategize the reform steps and identify the necessary 
combination of policy measures, the impacts on rural economies, farmers’ lives, and local 
governments’ fiscal conditions must be estimated. 
  
10.  MOF’s Tax Policy Department (TPD) is responsible for designing tax policies, including 
tax items, bases, rates, and advantages. A working team was established in the State Council 
to lead the rural tax and fee reforms, and the team’s secretariat was established within MOF. 
MOF’s Agricultural Department is responsible for state expenditures on agriculture, and the 
Budget Department for the revenue transfer system. STA is responsible for collecting VAT and 
other  national  taxes  through  its  widespread  local  offices.  Each  province  has  a  local  tax 
administration (LTA), which collects income, land-usage, and other local taxes. Some LTAs also 
collect agricultural taxes. In many provinces, local governments (counties and prefectures) 
collect agricultural taxes. The coordination between these different government departments is 
key for successful reform of agricultural taxes. 
 
11.  Asian Development Bank's Operations and Strategy. ADB has been helping the 
Government improve public administration and fiscal management through several projects 
such as Fiscal Management Reforms9 and the Study of Subprovincial Fiscal Relations.10 MOF is 
requesting the World Bank for advice on rural public finance, focusing on state expenditure. The 
TA for agricultural taxation reform will complement the World Bank’s assistance by focusing on 
the revenue side of rural public finance. ADB’s operational program in the Country Strategy and 
Program includes supporting reforms to improve the fiscal transfer system to help poor areas 
and focusing on fiscal reforms in agriculture and rural development. The program emphasizes 
that  agricultural  growth  and  adjustment  as  well  as  rural  development  are  key  to  reducing 
poverty. 
 
III.  THE  TEC HNICAL  ASSISTANCE
A.  Purpose and Output 
12.  The purpose of the TA is to help the Government replace the outdated, distorting, and 
disproportionate agricultural tax system with modern, fair, neutral, and unified urban and rural 
tax systems that will reduce the burden on poor farmers and encourage rural development. The 
TA will be divided into (i) studies on agricultural tax systems in the PRC and other countries,           
(ii) recommendations for new tax systems, and (iii) formulation of reform strategies. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
13.  The scope of TA includes the following: 
 
(i)  Study agricultural tax systems in the PRC and other countries  
 
(a)  Based on agricultural tax documents, identify key problems in the PRC’s 
agricultural  tax  system,  including  defects  in  implementation  and  the 
possible impact of solving these problems.

(b)  Learn from other countries. Identify solutions to problems in the domestic 
study.  Design  a  new  agricultural  tax  system  and  implementation 
arrangements. Compare  international agricultural tax systems. 
 
(ii)  Recommend agricultural tax systems that are equitable, revenue elastic, and 
suitable for the PRC. Encourage rural development on the basis of domestic and 
international studies 
 
(iii)  Formulate strategies to implement the new system 
 
(a)  Estimate  the  tax  reform’s  possible  impacts  on  and  benefits  for  rural 
economies,  farmers’  lives,  and  fiscal  condition  of  different  levels  of 
governments in different regions. 
(b)  Recommend strategies to shift to the new tax systems, including time 
frame, priorities, sequencing, conditions for important steps, and policy 
combinations. 
(c)  Through international and domestic training programs, give government 
officials  opportunities  to  assimilate  the  best  international  practices  in 
agricultural tax policy and administration. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
14.  The total TA cost is estimated at $650,000 equivalent, comprising a foreign exchange 
cost of $305,000 and a local currency cost of $345,000 equivalent. The Government has 
requested ADB to finance $500,000 equivalent, covering the entire foreign exchange cost and 
$195,000 equivalent of the local currency cost. The Government will finance the local currency 
cost, equivalent to $150,000, by providing counterpart staff, office space, and contingencies. 
The TA will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s TA funding program. The detailed TA cost 
estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
15.  TPD will be the Executing Agency. A working group will be established, led by the 
department’s top management, as the consultants’ counterpart TPD will provide office space, 
counterpart staff, in-city transportation, and other services to the consultants, and will arrange 
their appointments with agencies and organizations.  
 
16.  The  TA  will  require  a  total  of  17  person-months’  services  of  consultants:  three 
international for 7 person-months, and three domestic for 10 person-months. The international 
consultants will include an agricultural tax policy specialist and economist, a tax administration 
specialist, and a rural development planner and sociologist. Domestic consultants will have the 
same expertise. The outline terms of reference for consultants are in Appendix 3. They will be 
recruited through their firms, selected under the quality- and cost-based selection method using 
the  simplified  technical  proposal  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of 
Consultants  and  other  arrangements  satisfactory  to  ADB  on  the  engagement  of  domestic 
consultants. 
 
17.  The consultants will submit (i) an inception report within 1 month after they start working, 
(ii) two interim reports within 5 and 8 months, (iii) a draft final report before the contract ends, 
and (iv) the final report after incorporating TPD’s and ADB's comments. All reports will be in 
English and Chinese. The TA will start in November 2004 and be completed in November 2005.

5                         
   
Workshops  will  be  organized  near  the  end  of  implementation  to  invite  comments  from 
international and domestic experts and disseminate the project findings. After the first interim 
report, MOF and local agricultural tax administration staff will go on short-term visits to selected 
countries whose tax practices and methodologies might be useful for the PRC.11 An advance 
payment  facility  will  help  the  Government  organize  workshops  and  training  visits  abroad. 
Consultants will produce TA equipment in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines for Procurement. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the People’s Republic of China for the Agricultural Taxation Reform Project, 
and hereby reports this action to the Board.

Each team will consist of four or five officials, including MOF and LTA or local government staff. The participants 
will be endorsed by ADB before the visits. The participants will submit reports to TPD and ADB after the visits and 
give presentations in the domestic training workshop.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Outputs 
1.  The  expected  output  of  the  technical  assistance  (TA)  is  a  comprehensive  report 
recommending agricultural tax system reform. The report will contain (i) a domestic study on the 
agricultural  tax  system,  (ii)  an  international  study  on  agricultural  tax  systems,                        
(iii) recommendations for a new tax system, (iv) an analysis of the impacts of the transformation 
to the new tax system, and (v) a strategy for shifting to the new tax system. 
 
1.  Domestic Study on the Agricultural Tax System 
2.  To clarify the reform’s departure point and identify the TA issues, recent changes and 
the problems of the agricultural tax system in the People’s Republic of China (PRC) must be 
understood. Researches in this area should be fully used. The consultants will deepen the 
research to prepare policy recommendations and an implementation strategy by, among other 
things, sending questionnaires to local governments and conducting field research in selected 
regions. This part of the report will identify key issues, including the following: 
 
(i)  current agricultural tax regulations, and changes in regulations under the rural tax 
and fee reforms; 
 
(ii)  influences  of  past  and  current  agricultural  tax  systems  on  farmers’  income 
generation activities and living standards, and rural growth; 
 
(iii)  current systems for other taxes, including income and property taxes, and value-
added tax (VAT); 
 
(iv)  fiscal, public finance balance, and distributive justice aspects of the agricultural 
tax system; 
 
(v)  progress of rural tax and fee reforms and lessons learned; 
 
(vi)  staffing and operational efficiencies of local governments and their influence on 
fiscal conditions and supply of public services; and 
 
(vii)  methods and practices of tax collection, and division of labor between different 
government authorities, especially in rural areas. 
 
2.  International Study on the Agricultural Tax System 
3.  To solve the problems identified by the domestic study, agricultural tax systems in a 
wide range of countries should be studied. These systems differ widely, depending on overall 
tax  policy,  fiscal  relationship  between  different  levels  of  governments,  tax  administration 
capacities,  economic  development  stages,  economic  shares  of  sectors,  and  historical 
backgrounds.1  The  consultants  will  gather  information  about  other  countries’  practices  by 
collecting published materials, sending questionnaires to tax authorities of the target countries, 
                                                 
1  The countries of research may include Australia, Brazil, Canada, France, Germany, India, Indonesia, Japan, the 
Philippines, Republic of Korea, United Kingdom, and the United States.

10  Appendix 3 
and identifying key inputs to design a tax system. This part of the report will include the 
following: 
 
(i)  whether  the  countries  have  dual  or  unified  tax  systems  for  urban  and  rural 
residents; 
 
(ii)  the proportion of each source of income to total rural tax revenue; 
 
(iii)  income  tax  regulations,  including  tax  bases;  and  a  methodology  for  taxing 
agricultural  income,  including  tax  rates,  tax  exemption,  and  other  special 
preferable treatments; 
 
(iv)  VAT calculation for agricultural production, including implicit and explicit relief 
and rebates; 
 
(v)  property tax regulations, including tax bases and assessment methodologies, 
and grazing and commerce on agricultural land; 
 
(vi)  other revenue sources that are important in taxing farmers and rural residents; 
 
(vii)  the level of government that decides tax rates, collects taxes, and receives tax 
revenues for each tax item; 
 
(viii)  distribution of revenue between different levels of government; 
 
(ix)  fiscal transfer system between different levels of government; 
 
(x)  collection methods and practices for income tax, VAT, property tax, and other 
revenue sources that are important in taxing farmers and rural residents; 
 
(xi)  organizational structure, staff allocation, and division of labor in tax administration 
authorities; and 
 
(xii)  equitable, efficient, transparent, and revenue-elastic policies and practices that 
can be adapted to the PRC. 
 
3.  Recommendations for a Tax System 
4.  Based on the domestic and international studies, the consultants will recommend a tax 
system consistent with international best practices, suitable for a market economy, equitable, 
revenue elastic, and encouraging of rural development. The recommendations related to taxes 
applied to farmers, tax bases, authorities that decide tax rates, tax collection methods and 
division of labor, and distribution of the tax revenues between different levels of governments. 
 
4.  Analysis of the Impacts of the Transformation to the New Tax System 
5.  To strategize the steps and coordinate the shift to a new tax system, the consultants will 
analyze  the  transformation  impacts  with  econometric  exercises  using  limited  data.  The 
consultants will estimate the impacts of the recommended tax reforms on

Appendix 3  11 
(i)  public finance of different levels of government in different regions; 
 
(ii)  rural economies in different regions; and 
 
(iii)  farmers’ living standards, and rural development in different regions. 
 
5.  Strategy to Shift to the New Tax System 
6.  In conjunction with the studies, the consultants will identify the conditions to sequence 
reforms to the new tax system, identify the policy combination to offset negative impacts, and 
recommend the strategy and time frame to shift to the new system. 
 
6.  Report Submission Requirements 
7.  The consultants will submit the following: 
 
(i)  an inception report, summarizing the initial findings and detailed working plans, 
and suggesting changes needed in the Tax Policy Department’s approach, within 
1 month after services start; 
 
(ii)  the first interim report, compiling domestic and international studies’ findings 
within five months after services start; 
(iii)  the  second  interim  report  incorporating  the  comments  from  the  Ministry  of 
Finance (MOF) and Asian Development Bank (ADB) on the international and 
domestic  study  in  the  first  interim  report,  and  recommending  policy  and 
implementation strategies within eight months after services start;  
(iv)  a draft final report, well before the contract ends; and 
(v)  the final report, after incorporating comments from MOF and ADB and from 
international and domestic experts received during the workshops. 
 
B.  International Consultants (7 person-months) 
 
1.  Team Leader, Agricultural Tax Policy Specialist and Economist (4 person-
months) 
 
8.  As team leader, the consultant will be responsible for overall TA management and 
implementation; timely delivery of outputs, including interim and final reports; and recruitment 
and management of resource persons for various technical tasks. As the agricultural tax policy 
specialist, the consultant will take the lead in tax policy-related tasks in the international study 
(sections A2[i]–[ix] and [xii]) and recommendations for a new tax system (section A3). The 
specialist must have experience in policy areas of agriculture-related taxation, and sufficient 
knowledge of the PRC’s tax system. Other than preparing the reports, the consultant will also do 
the following: 
 
(i)  In consultation with other consultants, organize meetings between consultants 
and government agencies such as the various departments of the MOF, Ministry 
of Agriculture, State Taxation Administration, working group on rural tax and fee

reforms, and local governments to disseminate the consultants’ findings, invite 
comments, and improve coordination between governments at the completion of 
each interim report. 
 
(ii)  Organize overseas studies for Government officials to learn about agricultural tax 
policies, revenue collection, and public finance from other governments.  
 
(iii)  Near  the  end  of  implementation,  organize  workshops  of  international  and 
domestic experts and other stakeholders, and domestic training programs to 
disseminate the project findings and invite comments. 
 
2.  Tax Administration Specialist (1.5 person-months) 
 
9.  In consultation with the agricultural tax policy specialist and economist, the consultant 
will take the lead in tasks related to revenue collection methods and practices (sections A1[vii], 
A2[x]–[xi],  and  relevant  parts  of  A3  and  A5).  The  specialist  must  have  experience  in  tax 
administration, especially in rural areas. Other than preparing the reports, the consultant will 
also train tax administration staff members to improve their capacities and collection methods. 
 
3.  Rural Development Planner and Sociologist (1.5 person-months) 
 
10.  In consultation with the agricultural tax policy specialist and economist, the consultant 
will jointly take the lead with the domestic consultant in tasks related to rural development and 
farmers’ living standards (sections A1[ii] and A1[iv]–[vi]) and in impact analysis and strategy

C.  Domestic Consultants (3, 10 person-months total) 
 
11.  The consultants will have extensive in-depth country and sector knowledge and good 
contacts with the Government. The domestic consultants will help the international consultants 
become familiar with their tasks by (i) translating various documents to English; (ii) researching 
and compiling government policies, regulations, and procedures; and (iii) ensuring that the 
international consultants’ the output is appropriate for the PRC. The domestic consultants will 
lead in conducting the domestic study (section A1), formulating strategies to shift to a new tax 
system  (section  A5),  and  coordinating  with  various  government  agencies.  The  domestic 
consultants are expected to possess sufficient experience in their fields and have an excellent 
command of English. The consultants include the following:  
 
(i)  Agricultural tax policy specialist and economist (5 person-months). He or 
she will lead overall coordination of the domestic study (section A1), economic 
and  fiscal  aspects  of  the  impact  analysis  (section  A4),  and  design  of  the 
transition strategy (section A5). He or she will help the international consultant 
conduct the international study (section A2) and recommend a new tax system 
(section A3) to ensure that the outputs are appropriate to the PRC. 
 
(ii)  Tax administration specialist (2 person-months). He or she will lead the tax 
administration-related  part  of  the  domestic  study  (sections  A2[x]–[xi])  and 
transition  strategy  formulation  (section  A5).  The  specialist  will  help  the
